content.introduction: Classical music isn't as complicated as you think. Today, we'll prove it.
content.keyInsight: Classical music is simply organized sound telling stories and expressing emotions—just like any other music. The only difference is the vocabulary.

mainLesson.title: The Three Things You Need to Know

points.title: Melody
points.description: The tune you can hum. Every piece has at least one memorable melody.

points.title: Rhythm
points.description: The pulse and pattern. Classical music has driving rhythms, gentle sways, and everything between.

points.title: Structure
points.description: How it's organized. Most pieces repeat and develop ideas—listen for the return of familiar themes.

listenToday.whyThisPiece: The most famous four notes in music. You already know them. Now hear how Beethoven builds an entire movement from them.
whatToListenFor: The triumphant horn call in the middle

termOfTheDay.definition: A self-contained section of a larger work. Think of chapters in a book. A symphony usually has 4 movements.

content.introduction: An orchestra is like a city: different neighborhoods (sections), each with its own character, working together.
content.keyInsight: Once you can identify instrument families, the orchestra stops being a blur of sound and becomes a conversation between distinct voices.

points.title: Strings
points.description: The foundation. Violins, violas, cellos, basses. They can sing, whisper, or roar. Make up about 60% of the orchestra.

points.title: Woodwinds
points.description: The colors. Flutes, oboes, clarinets, bassoons. Each has a distinct personality—listen for solo melodies passed between them.

points.title: Brass
points.description: The power. Trumpets, horns, trombones, tubas. Used for grandeur, nobility, and climaxes. A little goes a long way.

points.title: Percussion
points.description: The punctuation. Timpani, cymbals, triangle. They mark important moments and add drama or color.

listenToday.piece: Britten: The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra
listenToday.whyThisPiece: Britten literally introduces each instrument family with a theme that showcases their character. It's classical music's best self-guided tour.
whatToListenFor: How each section has a distinct color
The grand finale bringing everyone together
listenToday.youtubeSearch: Britten Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra

termOfTheDay.definition: The art of choosing which instruments play which parts. Great orchestrators make the same notes sound completely different.

content.introduction: Classical music spans 400+ years. Each era has a distinct sound—once you hear the differences, you can place almost any piece.
content.keyInsight: Baroque = ornate and energetic. Classical = balanced and clear. Romantic = emotional and big. Modern = experimental and colorful.

points.title: Baroque (1600-1750)
points.description: Ornamental, energetic, harpsichord-driven. Think Bach, Vivaldi, Handel. Sounds: constant motion, decoration, terraced dynamics.

points.title: Classical (1750-1820)
points.description: Elegant, balanced, clear. Think Haydn, Mozart, early Beethoven. Sounds: graceful phrases, wit, symmetry.

points.title: Romantic (1820-1900)
points.description: Emotional, personal, expansive. Think Chopin, Brahms, Tchaikovsky. Sounds: big orchestras, long melodies, drama.

points.title: Modern (1900-today)
points.description: Experimental, diverse, colorful. Think Debussy, Stravinsky, Glass. Sounds: new harmonies, rhythm experiments, surprise.

listenToday.piece: A Mini-Tour Through Time (3 short excerpts)
listenToday.whyThisPiece: Hearing is believing. Three minutes from each era will train your ear instantly.
whatToListenFor: Baroque: Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3 (constant motion, bright energy)
Romantic: Chopin's Nocturne Op. 9 No. 2 (singing melody, emotional freedom)
Modern: Debussy's Arabesque No. 1 (floating harmony, dreamy atmosphere)
listenToday.spotifySearch: Bach Brandenburg 3 / Chopin Nocturne Op 9 / Debussy Arabesque

termOfTheDay.definition: A span of time in music history with shared stylistic features. Also called an 'era.' Knowing periods helps you set expectations before listening.

badge.name: Time Traveler
badge.description: You can navigate classical music history

content.introduction: Every building has an architecture. So does every piece of music. Understanding form turns chaos into story.
content.keyInsight: The most important form is 'Sonata Form': introduce themes (A & B), develop them, then bring them back changed. It's the foundation of symphonies and concertos.

points.title: Binary (AB)
points.description: Two parts. Simple songs often use this: verse-chorus-repeat.

points.title: Ternary (ABA)
points.description: Three parts where the third brings back the first. Like a sandwich—the return is satisfying.

points.title: Sonata Form
points.description: Exposition (meet the themes) → Development (themes get transformed) → Recapitulation (themes return home). The big one.

points.title: Rondo (ABACA...)
points.description: A main theme keeps returning between contrasting episodes. Great for upbeat finales.

listenToday.whyThisPiece: Perfect sonata form in action. The famous opening theme, the contrasting second theme, the development, and the triumphant return—all clearly audible.
whatToListenFor: 0:00 - First theme (agitated, minor key, famous melody)
5:00 - Recapitulation (first theme returns, now we're home)

termOfTheDay.definition: The most important structure in classical music. Three sections: Exposition (themes introduced), Development (themes explored), Recapitulation (themes return).

content.introduction: You now have the tools. The question is: what speaks to you?
content.keyInsight: There's no 'right' way to explore classical music. Follow your curiosity. If you love a piece, find more by that composer. If you love an era, explore its stars.

points.title: The Emotional Path
points.description: Start with how music makes you feel. Love drama? Try Beethoven, Brahms. Love calm? Try Bach, Debussy.

points.title: The Era Path
points.description: Pick an era that resonates and go deep. Listen to its major composers, understand its context.

points.title: The Composer Path
points.description: Find a composer you love and explore their full output. Hear how they evolved over their life.

points.title: The Form Path
points.description: Love symphonies? Listen to the great ones chronologically. Love piano? Explore the solo repertoire.

points.title: The Challenge Path
points.description: Set goals: all Beethoven symphonies, one new composer per month, a piece you initially found 'difficult.'

listenToday.piece: Your Choice from the Weekly Album
listenToday.whyThisPiece: Check this week's Album Pick and start your journey. Return to the app each week for new discoveries.
whatToListenFor: Questions that arise (look them up in the Glossary!)

termOfTheDay.definition: The collection of works a performer plays, or the body of works in a genre. Building your personal repertoire of pieces you know and love is the lifelong joy of classical music.

completionMessage.title: Congratulations!
completionMessage.message: You've completed the 5-Day Kickstart. You now have the foundation to explore classical music with confidence. Remember: every expert was once a beginner who kept listening.
